awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Virtual Lab for Coatings Design and Development
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide a software products that can catalyze high throughput design in the chemicals, materials, and energy space. The initial focus is to drastically cut the time to market, and development costs of functional organic coatings, which are under both regulatory and consumer pressure to develop custom solutions without loss of performance. An adjacent market is composites development, heavily dependent on fillers for its needs for lightweight materials. The computer-aided engineering market will be approximately $13 billion by 2025, while the industrial coatings market by itself is currently worth $115 billion globally. The benefits of these high-throughput solutions for development of advanced polymeric materials include reduced toxins and energy consumption.    

This I-Corps project leverages the use of molecular markers to develop a novel engineering design software for functional coatings. Using machine learning to correlate molecular markers to percolation threshold, and thereby failure through barrier ingress, the software would provide a unique method to down-select formulations to the most promising subset. The “virtual lab” approach is akin to high-throughput drug discovery. Current methods in coatings development fail to provide a physico-chemical or molecular underpinning to field performance and eventual failure. The design of experiments for coating assessment and formulation development commonly utilizes statistical software. This separation from mechanistic understanding often results in trial and error approaches, based largely on chemical intuition; furthermore, this leads to multiple accelerated aging runs that add significant lead time for field deployment of a given formulation as sub-optimal solutions. Developed software would provide a significant leap in design that translates to tailored polymeric advanced materials beyond functional coatings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Virtual Lab for Coatings Design and Development

Project Outcomes Report 

Award Title: I-Corps: Virtual Lab for Coatings Design and Development

Federal Award ID: 1952030

Report Submission Period: 02/01/2022 to 07/31/2022

The NSF ICORP grant helped our academic computational modeling team a clear perspective on the product market fit for our value proposition: that molecular modeling tools would shorten development time for the multibillion industrial coatings space instead of the laborious and expensive Design of Experiments approach that industry uses today. When we started, our team, composed of two researchers and an industrial mentor did not have a clear picture of the true value of our work product, which consists of developing theoretical models based on molecular dynamics simulations data. Our team was very confident that our custom modeling and simulation tools would be embraced by our potential customers  in the organic and inorganic industrial coating space. We had hypothesized that everybody in a target market that made complex chemical products like adhesives and paints would jump at the chance to forgo the complexities and costs of years of development using designer tools to predict properties and performance.

Our 200+ interviews over the life of the grant allowed us to interview almost everybody in this ecosystem, starting with laboratory technicians and lab managers, to technology sales and marketing  leadership. Our conclusion was that the software tools that they needed now, was not in the computational space where there was not the biggest pain. What these labs and companies needed urgently was to reduce their training and development time of their technicians and engineers who did not have the experience and skill sets that aging, experienced  and sometimes retired scientists and technicians had developed over decades of formulation experience.  In other words, they needed software and tools to help shorten the process time from customer specifications to commercial trials with the customer. Software that could capture, codify and interpret this data to help guide the research team would be the game changer and reduce costs and development from the average 2- 3 years to a few months.

Our team was disappointed that our value proposition was not validated even though we attempted multiple pivots in the space to attempt to find a home. However, we did learn that the coating industry is moving towards better software tools as part of the overall developmental toolkit. Our ICORP student and PI both learned key lessons on how the commercial world operates, and we have come back as a team with renewed energy to develop better and more relevant tools that include our research as part of the broader development software ecosystem. We have decided not to move forward with starting a company, but we are having internal discussions on using this experience to license our work to customers we have interviewed and built a relationship. Our Technical Lead (PI) has developed a work culture in the laboratory that embraces interactions with industry and interviews “outside the building” as part of our research philosophy to guide us to hone our research that can make an impact on the outside world. In addition, our ICORP grant Entrepreneurial Lead found this experience so fulfilling i.e., finding immediate solutions that customer need and he decided to abandon the academic pathway as researcher and has branched out into full time consulting in this industrial space.


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Mesfin Tsige
